details.portfolioPiece: Sound Redesign Project for Assassin's Creed
details.description:
A sound redesign of the Assassin’s Creed Codename Hexe trailer, focused on creating an immersive, atmospheric soundscape that supports the trailer’s dark, eerie aesthetic. The goal was to tell a story through sound, using audio to evoke emotion, build tension, and enhance the narrative.

Original audio elements were crafted from scratch through a blend of foley recording with a personal microphone setup and sound synthesis using various VST plugins. Novum and IZotope played a key role in shaping ambient textures and haunting atmospheres. The main challenge was achieving rich, layered sounds under tight time constraints, solved through iterative design and targeted feedback.

Insania is a point-and-click psychological horror game that explores the fragile boundary between reality and delusion. The story follows Dr. James Cawley, a man confronting his crumbling sanity as he searches for a way home, only to uncover dark truths about his past, including the tragic loss of his daughter, Lily, and the blurred reality shaped by his own mind.

Developed with a team of six, the game features a sanity mechanic where player interactions trigger auditory and visual hallucinations, intensifying the psychological tension. Original audio was crafted using Ableton Live 11 and Adobe Audition, focusing on layered sounds—from distorted environmental effects to disorienting whispers.

Key contributions include designing immersive sound effects, shaping the core game mechanics, and co-creating the narrative structure. The result is a compelling, story-driven experience that pulls players deep into the fractured reality of the protagonist’s mind.

IceAge is a 2.5D platformer blending 2D characters with a 3D environment, created for The Monster Project. The game follows IceAge, a frost fairy on a quest to reclaim stolen ice crystals and save her transformed ice sparks from a vengeful fire demon. Developed with a team of six, the project involved collaboration with Concordia Enschede and International School Twente, with a final showcase presented to the children who inspired the game’s monsters. My key roles included leading the team through task management, planning, and execution, as well as UI design, sound effects, and gameplay mechanics. I also focused on game testing and iterative design to refine puzzle-solving, companion-based gameplay, and dynamic environments.

Dad’s Day Out is a serious game that explores the challenges and nuances of modern parenting. The player steps into the role of a father navigating daily life, balancing work responsibilities with the emotional and developmental needs of his child. The game’s core objective is to reflect on parenting styles, with outcomes influenced by the player's in-game decisions and time management.

Developed with a team of six, the game features an isometric 3D environment where players move through the house, completing various tasks. Each household chore is designed as a unique 2D mini-game, ranging from watering plants to drawing with the child, emphasizing the contrast between routine responsibilities and quality bonding moments. The game’s economy system analyzes player behavior to determine their parenting style, offering insightful feedback based on choices made.

Key contributions include sound design, gameplay mechanics, and shaping the overall game experience to foster reflection on parent-child dynamics.

Light Logic is a physics-based puzzle game focused on manipulating light to solve challenges using optical elements like mirrors, prisms, lenses, and filters. Players must strategically place and adjust these elements to guide light beams toward targets while overcoming obstacles and progressively complex level designs.

The game is structured across three stages, each introducing new mechanics that enhance problem-solving and spatial reasoning. Real-world physics principles, including Snell’s Law and the Law of Reflection, were implemented to ensure realistic light behavior. Phydemo was used to prototype light physics, refining mechanics for an intuitive and engaging experience.

This project combines technical research, level design, and gameplay mechanics, delivering an interactive and immersive puzzle experience that challenges players to think critically about light and optics.

A custom-built sound-reactive lighting system designed to enhance a personal record collection with interactive LED effects. The project integrates an ESP32 microcontroller, WLED firmware, and an analog microphone to sync LED visuals with audio, creating a dynamic and immersive ambiance.

The system uses a 12V WS2815 LED strip, powered via a 220V to 12V transformer, with sound-reactive features that adjust brightness and color based on detected frequency and amplitude variations. WAGO connectors and breadboard cables facilitated rapid prototyping, while the Arduino IDE was used for firmware iteration and fine-tuning.

This project merges electronics, programming, and creative lighting design, demonstrating a hands-on approach to interactive installations.

Plethora of Game Sounds is a meticulously crafted sound library designed for game developers, offering 146 high-quality sound effects in both WAV and OGG Vorbis formats. The collection is divided into three main categories—Ambience, Foley, and Synthesized—providing a versatile selection of sounds for various game environments.

To ensure efficient workflow, the asset list was structured using the Universal Category System, allowing for clear organization and easy implementation. Sounds were created through a blend of foley recording (using a Rode NTG3, Zoom H5, Rode NT-1A) and sound synthesis (using Ableton Live 11, Phase Plant, and Serum). Metadata was refined using MP3Tag, ensuring accessibility and proper categorization.

Published on itch.io, this library delivers studio-quality audio assets ranging from atmospheric ambiences to detailed foley and synthesized game effects, all formatted for seamless integration into interactive experiences.

The Green Gaming Paper is an in-depth industry report exploring Ecogames and sustainable game development practices. Developed collaboratively by a team of 55 students, the paper analyzes how video games incorporate environmental themes and how the industry can adopt greener production methods.

Contributions to the paper include writing the Ecogames – Representation in Games chapter, compiling and refining a dataset of researched games, and creating data visualizations using Tableau and R to highlight global trends in ecogame development. Additionally, contributions to the Green Game Production – Good Practices chapter involved structuring and editing research on sustainable game development, ensuring clarity and alignment with the paper’s goals.

This project provides insights into how games can be both a platform for environmental awareness and an industry striving for sustainability.
